prior_works.title: Learning Quickly When Irrelevant Attributes Abound: A New Linear-threshold Algorithm
prior_works.role: Foundational concept (Littlestone dimension and mistake trees)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s mistake and regret lower bounds are parameterized by the Littlestone dimension and use shattering/mistake-tree arguments that directly build on Littlestone’s framework and SOA analysis.

prior_works.title: Agnostic Online Learning
prior_works.authors: Shai Ben-David, Dávid Pál, Shai Shalev-Shwartz
prior_works.role: Baseline characterization of online learnability and agnostic regret
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the standard online benchmarks (realizable mistake bounds and agnostic regret) against which the new ERM-oracle-constrained lower bounds are contrasted and extended.

prior_works.title: Online Learning via Sequential Complexities
prior_works.role: Lower-bound technique via tree-based/sequential complexity arguments
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The agnostic lower-bound methodology—deriving Ω(√T·complexity) rates from tree-based sequential complexity—underlies the present work’s regret lower bounds, which show how ERM-oracle constraints inflate the effective complexity to 2^{d_LD}.

prior_works.title: Efficient Algorithms for Online Decision Problems
prior_works.role: Oracle-efficient online learning (FPL using optimization/ERM oracles)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the paradigm of implementing online learners via optimization/ERM oracles, providing the algorithmic baseline and modeling choice that this paper quantifies in terms of the number of oracle calls.

prior_works.title: The Computational Power of Optimization in Online Learning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Directly inspires the paper’s focus on tradeoffs between performance (mistakes/regret) and calls to an optimization/ERM oracle, and the development of tight lower bounds under oracle-access constraints.

prior_works.title: Queries and Concept Learning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Motivates the weak consistency oracle used here—testing realizability of labeled subsets—and informs reductions and hardness arguments based on limited oracle access to the concept class.

prior_works.title: Agnostic Active Learning
prior_works.authors: Maria-Florina Balcan, Alina Beygelzimer, John Langford
prior_works.role: Transductive/pool-based perspective using version spaces and ERM/consistency checks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The transductive online protocols with unlabeled pools and version-space consistency checks mirror active-learning setups, guiding the paper’s oracle interface (ERM vs. realizability) and its mistake–query tradeoff analysis.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—tight tradeoffs between mistakes/regret and the number of ERM or weak consistency oracle calls in online and transductive online learning—rests on three pillars: the Littlestone-dimension view of online learnability, the oracle-efficient paradigm for online algorithms, and sequential lower-bound techniques. Littlestone (1988) provides the combinatorial backbone: mistake trees and the Littlestone dimension d_LD characterize realizable-case online classification, and this work expresses its lower bounds explicitly in terms of 2^{d_LD}, leveraging tree-shattering structure. Ben-David, Pál, and Shalev-Shwartz (2009) supply the standard realizable and agnostic online benchmarks, clarifying what is achievable with full concept-class access; the new results show these guarantees fundamentally degrade when access is restricted to ERM/consistency oracles. Rakhlin and Sridharan’s sequential complexity framework informs the agnostic regret analysis: tree-based constructions yielding Ω(√T·complexity) are adapted to demonstrate how ERM-only access amplifies the effective complexity to 2^{d_LD}, producing the stated Ω(√T·2^{d_LD}) lower bound. On the computational side, Kalai–Vempala (2005) and Hazan–Koren (2016) establish the oracle-efficient lens—learning via offline optimization/ERM oracles and intrinsic tradeoffs between performance and oracle usage—directly motivating the paper’s metric of oracle calls and its matching lower bounds. Finally, Angluin’s query-model formalism and active-learning work by Balcan–Beygelzimer–Langford anchor the weak consistency oracle and the transductive/pool-based setting: realizability checks and version-space reasoning guide the model and reductions used to relate mistakes to oracle-call complexity.
